One afternoon, a Sunday, a new model TFord2
slowly came up
the hill and went past the house. The boy, who happened to see it
from the porch, ran down the steps and stood on the sidewalk. The
driver was looking right and left as if trying to find a particular ad
dress; he turned the car around at the corner and came back. Pulling
up before the boy, he idled his throttle and beckoned with a gloved
hand. He was a Negro. His car shone. The brightwork gleamed… I
am looking for a young woman of color whose name is Sarah, be said.
She is said to reside in one of these houses.
The boy realized he meant the woman in the attic. She’s here. The
man switched off the motor, set the brake and jumped down.
When Mother came to the door the colored man was respectful,
but there was something disturbingly resolute and selfimportant
in the way he asked her if he could please speak with Sarah. Mother
could not judge his age. He was a stocky man with a redcomplect
ed shining brown face, high cheekbones and large dark eyes so in
tense as to suggest they were about to cross. He had a neat mous
tache. He was dressed in the affection of wealth to which colored
people lent themselves.
She told him to wait and closed the door. She climbed to the
third floor. She found the girl Sarah not sitting at the window as
she usually did but standing rigidly, hands folded in front of her,
and facing the door. Sarah, Mother said, you have a caller. The girl
said nothing. Will you come to the kitchen? The girl shook her head.
You don’t want to see him? No, ma’am, the girl finally said softly,
while she looked at the floor. Send him away, please. This was the
most she had said in all the months she had lived in the house. Moth
er went back downstairs and found the fellow not at the back door
but in the kitchen where, in the warmth of the comer near the cook
stove, Sarah’s baby lay sleeping in his carriage. The black man was
kneeling beside the carriage and staring at the child. Mother, not
thinking clearly, was suddenly outraged that he had presumed to
come in the door. Sarah is unable to see you, she said and she held
the door open. The colored man took another glance at the child,
rose, thanked her and departed.
Such was the coming of the colored man in the car to Broad
view Avenue. His name was Coalhouse Walker Jr. Beginning with
that Sunday he appeared every week, always knocking at the back
door. Always turning away without complaint upon Sarah’s re
fusal to see him. Father considered the visits a nuisance and want
ed to discourage them. I’ll call the police, he said. Mother laid her
hand on his arm. One Sunday the colored man left a bouquet of
yellow chrysanthemums which in this season had to have cost him
a pretty penny.
The black girl would say nothing about her visitor. They had no
idea where she had met him, or how. As far as they knew she had no
family nor any friends from the black community in the downtown
section of the city. Apparently she had come by herself from New
York to work as a servant. Mother was exhilarated by the situation.
She began to regret Sarah’s intransigence. She thought of the drive
from Harlem, where Coalhouse Walker Jr. lived, and the drive back,
and she decided the next time to give him more of a visit. She would
serve tea in the parlor. Father questioned the propriety of this.
Mother said, he is wellspoken and conducts himself as a gentle
man. I see nothing wrong with it. When Mr Roosevelt3
was in the
White House he gave dinner to Booker T. Washington. Surely we
can serve tea to Coalhouse Walker Jr.
And so it happened on the next Sunday that the Negro took tea.
Father noted that he suffered no embarrassment by being in the parlor with a cup and saucer in his hand. On the contrary, he acted as if it
was the most natural thing in the world. The surroundings did not
awe him nor was his manner deferential. He was courteous and cor
rect. He told them about himself. He was a professional pianist and
was now more or less permanently located in New York, having se
cured a job with the Jim Europe Clef Club Orchestra, a wellknown
ensemble that gave regular concerts at the Manhattan4
Casino on 155th Street and Eighth Avenue. It was important, he said, for a musician to find a place that was permanent, a job that required no travelling… I am through travelling, he said. I am through going on the
road. He spoke so fervently that Father realized the message was in
tended for the woman upstairs. This irritated him. What can you play?
he said abruptly. Why don’t you play something for us?
The black man placed tea on the tray. He rose, patted his lips with
the napkin, placed the napkin beside his cup and went to the piano.
He sat on the piano stool and immediately rose and twirled it till the
height was to his satisfaction. He sat down again, played a chord and
turned to them. This piano is badly in need of a tuning, he said. Fa
ther’s face reddened. Oh, yes. Mother said, we are terrible about that.
The musician turned again to the keyboard. “Wall Street5
Rag,” he
said. Composed by the great Scott Joplin.6
He began to play. Illtunedor not the Aeolian had never made such sounds. Small clear chords
hung in the air like flowers. The melodies were like bouquets. There
seemed to be no other possibilities for life than those delineated by
the music. When the piece was over Coalhouse Walker turned on the
stool and found in his audience the entire family: Mother, Father, the
boy, Grandfather and Mother’s Younger Brother, who had come down
from his room in shirt and suspenders to see who was playing. Of all
of them he was the only one who knew ragtime. He had heard it in his
nightlife period in New York. He had never expected to hear it in his
sister’s home.
Coalhouse Walker Jr. turned back to the piano and said “The
Maple Leaf”. Composed by the great Scott Joplin. The most famous
rag of all rang through the air. The pianist sat stiffly at the key
board, his long dark hands with their pink nails seemingly with no
effort producing the clusters of syncopating chords and the thump
ing octaves. This was a most robust composition, a vigorous music
that roused the senses and never stood still a moment. The boy per
ceived it as light touching various places in space, accumulating in
intricate patterns until the entire room was made to glow with its
own being. The music filled the stairwell to the third floor where the mute and unforgiving Sarah sat with her hands folded and lis
tened with the door open.
The piece was brought to a conclusion. Everyone applauded. Moth
er then introduced Mr Walker to Grandfather and to Younger Brother,
who shook the black man’s hand and said I am pleased to meet you.
Coalhouse Walker was solemn. Everyone was standing. There was a
silence. Father cleared his throat. Father was not knowledgeable in
music. His taste ran to Carrie Jacobs Bond.7
He thought Negro music
had to have smiling and cakewalkmg. Do you know any coon songs?8
he said. He did not intend to be rude — coon songs was what they
were called. But the pianist responded with a tense shake of the head.
Coon songs are made for minstrel shows,9
he said. White men sing
them in blackface. There was another silence. The black man looked
at the ceiling. Well, he said, it appears as if Miss Sarah will not be able
to receive me. He turned abruptly and walked through the hall to the

walked out of the door.

Stylistic Analysis:

The passage begins with a description of the arrival of Coalhouse Walker Jr., a Negro man, in his shiny new model T Ford car. The writing in this passage is simple and straightforward, with clear sentences and direct language. The use of short, declarative sentences creates a sense of urgency and immediacy in the narrative.

The description of Coalhouse Walker Jr. himself is vivid and detailed, with his shining brown face, high cheekbones, and large, intense eyes. The strong, physical description of the character is contrasted with the quiet, reserved demeanor of Sarah, the woman he has come to see. This contrast emphasizes the importance of their upcoming interaction.

As Coalhouse Walker Jr. begins to come to the house every week, the narrative shifts to focus on the reactions of the family to his visits. The writing becomes more detailed and descriptive, focusing on the small interactions between characters and their emotions. This change in style reflects the increasing importance of Coalhouse Walker Jr. in their lives.

The dialogue in the passage is naturalistic and realistic, with characters speaking in short, direct sentences that reflect their personalities and backgrounds. Father’s abrupt question about coon songs and Coalhouse Walker Jr.’s tense response highlight the racial tension and misunderstandings that exist between the characters.

Overall, the stylistic choices in the passage emphasize the importance of the arrival of Coalhouse Walker Jr. and the conflict that arises from his presence in the lives of the white family. The simple language and short sentences create a sense of urgency and immediacy, while the detailed descriptions and dialogue highlight the complex emotional dynamics between the characters.

do text analysis 

What do you remember most about your childhood? Running
through the long dewy grass of a meadow or the Saturday morning
TV cartoons? Sitting in the kitchen watching your mother cook sup
per or sitting in the livingroom watching Caprain Kangaroo!
1
 Which
came first on Sunday morning — breakfast or the comics?
Now bring your memories up to date. What did you and your
friends talk about, at least part of the time, before class? An item from
a newspaper? An ad that you noticed in a magazine or a television
commercial? An episode from a popular TV series? A movie? Or a
new record that you heard on the radio?
If your answers parallel those of most young people, you add to
the proof that mass media play a large and influential part in your
life. Your answers also prove just how casually you accept the media,
just as you accept the house you live in, cars, electricity, telephones,
your school, and your family as part of your environment. Parents
and teachers agree that all young people growing up with the media
learn from them sometimes more than adults wish you to. (And this
is the cause for alarm.)
If the use of them referring to media in the last sentence seems
strange, remember that the word media linguistically is plural. When
people make a fuss about the media being a bad influence, they usual
ly are talking about television, the most powerful medium of all. Maybe
calling television the media can be justified technically because, as a
medium, it embraces functions of several media such as newspapers,
magazines, movies, and recordings.
The major media can be divided into two kinds, print and elec
tronic. The print media — newspapers, magazines, books, pamphlets,
catalogues, circulars, brochures, anything you read — are the old
est, dating back to the invention of the printing press in the fif
teenth century. The electronic media — radio, television, films of all
kinds, records, tapes, anything that is transmitted by the use of elec
tricity — are less than a hundred years old.
Another meaning the word mass suggests is “the people”, a phrase
too often associated with adjectives like dullwitted, credulous, ill
informed, uncritical, and passive. Or are the mass of people wellin
formed, sophisticated, thoughtful, and active? Which are you? How
much of what you know about yourself has been taught you by the
media? You may not realize how greatly the media influence you be
cause in your lifetime they have always been there. In fact, short of
deliberate isolation on a mountain top or being lost in a forest and
reared by wolves, no one will ever again grow up without the pres
ence and influence of the mass media.
Is this good or bad?
An experiment recently conducted in Europe by the Society for
Rational Psychology showed that watching television is psychologi
cally addictive. The idea of becoming addicted to television brings
up questions involving subtle conditioning and brainwashing that
could be friendly or vicious, altruistic or selfserving.
In a commercial society the media’s ability to stimulate motiva
tion to buy — almost as though people were puppets on strings —
builds other people’s power. It can be power for good or power for
bad, but it is always power for control.
All these negative aspects of growing up with the media need con
sideration, at the same time you are enjoying the positive aspects of
immediately knowing what’s going on in the world, sharing great
entertainment and historical events with everyone else in our “glo
bal village”, and having the fun of trying out a new product that you
wouldn’t have known about without advertising.
According to a recent research report, more than a third of all chil
dren by the age of three are viewing TV with some regularity and
more than half are listening to books read to them. Before they are
old enough for school — a third of the children are looking through
magazines, 40 percent are listening to radio, and 80 percent are view
ing television. At age seven, newspapers enter a child’s life, usually
through the comic strips. You are one of these children. As you grew,
you absorbed uncritically, as children do.
189
And what did you absorb? Hundreds of items of information, most
of them accurate as far as they went. Increasing sophistication of taste
and appreciation of technical skills. High standards of performance
by talented musicians and actors that sometimes make your teachers
despair of competing effectively for your attention.
With all this, you also absorbed ideas about behaviour, about
right and wrong, good and bad, the permissible and the forbidden.
These ideas were presented to you — and still are — directly and
indirectly with the entertainment, advertising, and information. The
most powerful ideas are the ones you absorb indirectly. They are
digested emotionally at psychological depths that we still know lit
tle about, although we can tell that the effect of reaching those
depths is particularly strong and long lasting from behaviour pat
terns that emerge.
... Another indicating of media influence is in the language we use.
Whole new vocabularies come into existence with new inventions.
Look back at the first two paragraphs of this chapter. How many ex
pressions can you identify that came into popular usage with the de
velopment of a medium? How about TV cartoons? Or the abbreviat
ed version of the word television? In this country, we say TV and
spell it several different ways: tv, T.V., TV, teevee. In Britain, it’s the
telly, as everyone who watches the British “standup” comedian will
know. That term, standup comic, seems to be another media inven
tion. Actually, a comedian does sit sometimes, whenever the action of
a skit demands, but there is always that string of jokes, or wouldbe
jokes, delivered standing up, first at a stationary microphone during
early radio days, now just standing or wandering about a stage, mike
in hand. In advertising, the standup commercial was the first kind
used. In this, the announcer or star of the program would grasp the
product firmly in hand, making sure the name faced the camera, and
as persuasively as possible, recite or read the copy written about it at
an advertising agency.
Words introduced in the media frequently enlarge their meanings
far beyond the scope originally intended for them. How many mean
ings do the words Mickey Mouse have today? Which show approval?
Which disapproval?
The impact of the mass media is very strong. It changes our lan
guage, stimulates our emotions, informs our intellect, influences our
ideas, values, and attitudes. When you were young and absorbing
uncritically, you could not possibly know that the majority of the
material you saw and heard was designed to produce specific responses
190
from you. Some adults, for that matter, either do not know or refuse
to admit the following basic fact of media production: the MAJORI
TY of material is chosen or designed to produce a predetermined re
sponse. Even that part of media output called “entertainment” is cho
sen to keep you quiet, unquestioning, available, and receptive to
commercial messages inserted throughout. This is evident whether
the entertainment is a TV drama with commercials every few min
utes or a newspaper or magazine article with columns of type wrapped
around the advertisements.
The journalism, urgent issues, news, or informationgiving por
tion of media output is selected, edited, produced, placed in time slots
or positioned in the newspaper or magazine to reflect and support
the owner’s policies. However, no reporter, photographer, film or copy
editor, script or continuity writer in either print or electronic media
has ever needed to be told specifically what the boss’s policies are.
You pick them up through your pores within a week or two of accept
ing a job, and you work accordingly.
The owner’s policies, therefore, determine the response that the
media wish from you even if it’s only to keep quiet and accept. Then
the material is written, staged, photographed with or without audio,
printed and/or broadcast. We — counted in the millions, the mass
audience of mass media — are then programmed to buy, vote, con
tribute, believe, and support other people’s interests, interests which
may be commercial, political, charitable, philosophical, or educational.
Sometimes these interests will coincide with your own; sometimes
they won’t. Most of the time, the response comes in as programmed;
occasionally it doesn’t, or there is an additional, unexpected response.
Some of the media’s output has long lasting value and worth; some is
not only cheap, tawdry, and superficial stuff, but physically, emotional
ly, and intellectually harmful.

Text Analysis:

The passage begins by asking the reader to reflect on their childhood memories and how much of it was influenced by mass media. The tone is objective and informative, with a focus

The passage is written in a casual style, using simple, conversational language with occasional rhetorical questions and direct address to the reader. The author uses examples and personal anecdotes to connect with the reader and make their point. The paragraph length varies, sometimes being short and punchy, sometimes longer with more complex sentences.

The author also uses a variety of techniques to engage the reader and keep their interest. They start with questions about childhood memories before segueing into a discussion about the influence of the media on young people, a topic that they acknowledge may not be of immediate interest to the reader, but that they frame as relevant to their experience.

The author uses some rhetorical strategies to make their argument more persuasive. They use repetition, for example, to emphasize the ubiquity of the media in modern life ("they have always been there"). They also use loaded words like "alarm" and "addictive" to make the negative aspects of the media's influence seem more significant.

conversations.facetValue: perform a stylistic and text analysis.

allFacetValues.value: analyze a text about the influence of mass media on individuals, providing stylistic and text analysis.
English
perform a stylistic and text analysis.

conversation.content:
do stylistic analysis

What do you remember most about your childhood? Running through the long dewy grass of a meadow or the Saturday morning TV cartoons? Sitting in the kitchen watching your mother cook super or sitting in the livingroom watching Caprain Kangaroo!
Which came first on Sunday morning — breakfast or the comics?
Now bring your memories up to date. What did you and your friends talk about, at least part of the time, before class? An item from a newspaper? An ad that you noticed in a magazine or a television commercial? An episode from a popular TV series? A movie? Or a new record that you heard on the radio? If your answers parallel those of most young people, you add to the proof that mass media play a large and influential part in your life. Your answers also prove just how casually you accept the media, just as you accept the house you live in, cars, electricity, telephones, your school, and your family as part of your environment. Parents and teachers agree that all young people growing up with the media learn from them sometimes more than adults wish you to. (And this is the cause for alarm.) If the use of them referring to media in the last sentence seems strange, remember that the word media linguistically is plural. When people make a fuss about the media being a bad influence, they usual ly are talking about television, the most powerful medium of all. Maybe calling television the media can be justified technically because, as a medium, it embraces functions of several media such as newspapers, magazines, movies, and recordings. The major media can be divided into two kinds, print and elec tronic. The print media — newspapers, magazines, books, pamphlets, catalogues, circulars, brochures, anything you read — are the old est, dating back to the invention of the printing press in the fifteenth century. The electronic media — radio, television, films of all kinds, records, tapes, anything that is transmitted by the use of elec tricity — are less than a hundred years old. Another meaning the word mass suggests is “the people”, a phrase
too often associated with adjectives like dullwitted, credulous, ill
informed, uncritical, and passive. Or are the mass of people wellin
formed, sophisticated, thoughtful, and active? Which are you? How
much of what you know about yourself has been taught you by the
media? You may not realize how greatly the media influence you be
cause in your lifetime they have always been there. In fact, short of
deliberate isolation on a mountain top or being lost in a forest and
reared by wolves, no one will ever again grow up without the pres
ence and influence of the mass media.
Is this good or bad?
An experiment recently conducted in Europe by the Society for
Rational Psychology showed that watching television is psychologi
cally addictive. The idea of becoming addicted to television brings
up questions involving subtle conditioning and brainwashing that
could be friendly or vicious, altruistic or selfserving.
In a commercial society the media’s ability to stimulate motiva
tion to buy — almost as though people were puppets on strings —
builds other people’s power. It can be power for good or power for
bad, but it is always power for control.
All these negative aspects of growing up with the media need con
sideration, at the same time you are enjoying the positive aspects of
immediately knowing what’s going on in the world, sharing great
entertainment and historical events with everyone else in our “glo
bal village”, and having the fun of trying out a new product that you
wouldn’t have known about without advertising.
According to a recent research report, more than a third of all chil
dren by the age of three are viewing TV with some regularity and
more than half are listening to books read to them. Before they are
old enough for school — a third of the children are looking through
magazines, 40 percent are listening to radio, and 80 percent are view
ing television. At age seven, newspapers enter a child’s life, usually
through the comic strips. You are one of these children. As you grew,
you absorbed uncritically, as children do.
And what did you absorb? Hundreds of items of information, most
of them accurate as far as they went. Increasing sophistication of taste
and appreciation of technical skills. High standards of performance
by talented musicians and actors that sometimes make your teachers
despair of competing effectively for your attention.
With all this, you also absorbed ideas about behaviour, about
right and wrong, good and bad, the permissible and the forbidden.
These ideas were presented to you — and still are — directly and
indirectly with the entertainment, advertising, and information. The
most powerful ideas are the ones you absorb indirectly. They are
digested emotionally at psychological depths that we still know lit
tle about, although we can tell that the effect of reaching those
depths is particularly strong and long lasting from behaviour pat
terns that emerge.
… Another indicating of media influence is in the language we use.
Whole new vocabularies come into existence with new inventions.
Look back at the first two paragraphs of this chapter. How many ex
pressions can you identify that came into popular usage with the de
velopment of a medium? How about TV cartoons? Or the abbreviat
ed version of the word television? In this country, we say TV and
spell it several different ways: tv, T.V., TV, teevee. In Britain, it’s the
telly, as everyone who watches the British “standup” comedian will
know. That term, standup comic, seems to be another media inven
tion. Actually, a comedian does sit sometimes, whenever the action of
a skit demands, but there is always that string of jokes, or wouldbe
jokes, delivered standing up, first at a stationary microphone during
early radio days, now just standing or wandering about a stage, mike
in hand. In advertising, the standup commercial was the first kind
used. In this, the announcer or star of the program would grasp the
product firmly in hand, making sure the name faced the camera, and
as persuasively as possible, recite or read the copy written about it at
an advertising agency.
Words introduced in the media frequently enlarge their meanings
far beyond the scope originally intended for them. How many mean
ings do the words Mickey Mouse have today? Which show approval?
Which disapproval?
The impact of the mass media is very strong. It changes our lan
guage, stimulates our emotions, informs our intellect, influences our
ideas, values, and attitudes. When you were young and absorbing
uncritically, you could not possibly know that the majority of the
material you saw and heard was designed to produce specific responses
from you. Some adults, for that matter, either do not know or refuse
to admit the following basic fact of media production: the MAJORI
TY of material is chosen or designed to produce a predetermined re
sponse. Even that part of media output called “entertainment” is cho
sen to keep you quiet, unquestioning, available, and receptive to
commercial messages inserted throughout. This is evident whether
the entertainment is a TV drama with commercials every few min
utes or a newspaper or magazine article with columns of type wrapped
around the advertisements.
The journalism, urgent issues, news, or informationgiving por
tion of media output is selected, edited, produced, placed in time slots
or positioned in the newspaper or magazine to reflect and support
the owner’s policies. However, no reporter, photographer, film or copy
editor, script or continuity writer in either print or electronic media
has ever needed to be told specifically what the boss’s policies are.
You pick them up through your pores within a week or two of accept
ing a job, and you work accordingly.
The owner’s policies, therefore, determine the response that the
media wish from you even if it’s only to keep quiet and accept. Then
the material is written, staged, photographed with or without audio,
printed and/or broadcast. We — counted in the millions, the mass
audience of mass media — are then programmed to buy, vote, con
tribute, believe, and support other people’s interests, interests which
may be commercial, political, charitable, philosophical, or educational.
Sometimes these interests will coincide with your own; sometimes
they won’t. Most of the time, the response comes in as programmed;
occasionally it doesn’t, or there is an additional, unexpected response.
Some of the media’s output has long lasting value and worth; some is
not only cheap, tawdry, and superficial stuff, but physically, emotionally, and intellectually harmful.

The stylistic analysis of the given text provides insight into the author's use of language and structure to convey their message regarding the influence mass media plays in daily lives. The following aspects of style can be noted:

1. Use of rhetorical questions: The author starts the text with a series of questions which serves to engage the reader and provoke a sense of nostalgia. The text frequently uses this rhetorical device to encourage the reader to reflect on their experiences and question their assumptions, thus capturing the reader's attention.

2. Informal language and tone: The use of informal language, such as informal contractions ("you're") and colloquial expressions (e.g., "Captain Kangaroo") creates a conversational tone. This makes the text more accessible and less intimidating, allowing readers to feel more connected to the subject.

3. Repetition and parallelism: The author employs repetition of words and phrases, as well as parallel sentence structures, to emphasize important points (e.g., "The impact of the mass media is very strong."). This stylistic choice reinforces the central theme and provides consistency throughout the text.

4. Use of statistics and research: The author frequently cites statistics and research findings to support their claims about the media's influence on individuals. This evidence-based approach lends credibility to the arguments made and bolsters the author's position.

5. Exploration of both positive and negative aspects: The author takes a balanced approach, examining both the benefits and drawbacks of growing up with mass media. This allows the reader to form their own opinions on the topic and demonstrates the complexity of the issue.

6. Use of examples and anecdotes: Throughout the text, the author provides examples and anecdotes to illustrate various points, such as the way media influences language or how it can be used for good or bad purposes. These examples bring the concepts to life, making them more relatable and easier to understand.

7. Clear organization and structure: The text follows a clear and logical structure, with each paragraph tackling a different aspect of the media's influence. This aids comprehension and guides the reader smoothly through the discussion.

Overall, the author's stylistic choices contribute to a compelling and thought-provoking text that engages the reader and successfully illustrates the pervasive influence of mass media on everyday life.

The text revolves around the influence of mass media on individuals, particularly during their childhood and developmental years. The author explores various aspects of media exposure and its impact on people's lives. The following themes can be identified through a text analysis:

1. Media as an integral part of life: The author puts forth the idea that media is just as important and influential in a person's life as other environmental aspects such as their family, school, and the geographical place they live in. Nostalgia is used to establish the long-lasting presence of media in people's lives.

2. The power and reach of electronic media: The text discusses the omnipresence of media, specifically electronic media, and its influence on the development of knowledge, values, and attitudes in individuals. The author presents both positive and negative aspects of this phenomenon, highlighting its potential for both harmful and beneficial effects on people's lives.

3. Commercialization and manipulation: The author points out that in a commercial society, media is often designed to elicit specific responses from its audience, be it for purchasing a product or supporting certain political, charitable, or educational interests. This manipulative aspect of mass media raises questions about free will and autonomy.

4. Media's impact on language and communication: The text examines the way media shapes and transforms the language people use, through the introduction of new words, phrases, and ways of communicating. This demonstrates the pervasive nature of media in people's lives, even in how they communicate with one another.

5. The role of media owners and their interests: The author emphasizes that the content and policies of media outlets are determined by their owners, who often have specific agendas they want to promote. This further raises questions about the objectivity and neutrality of mass media.

6. The need for critical thinking and awareness: A recurring theme in the text is the necessity for individuals to develop critical thinking skills and awareness about the media they consume, so as not to be easily manipulated or influenced by its content.

In summary, the text aims to shed light on the profound impact of mass media on individuals, questioning its role in shaping their beliefs, values, and attitudes. It encourages readers to reflect on their own experiences with media and develop a critical understanding of its influence on their lives.

conversations.facetValue: perform a stylistic analysis on a given text passage.

allFacetValues.value: do text analysis on a passage describing an execution scene.
English
perform a stylistic analysis on a given text passage.

conversation.content:
do text analysis

He stood  and  faced them, smiling, and  the  carbines  shook  in their hands.
     "I am quite ready," he said.
     The lieutenant stepped forward, trembling  a little with excitement. He had never given the word of command for an execution before.
     "Ready-present-fire!"
     The Gadfly staggered  a little and recovered his balance. One  unsteady shot had  grazed his cheek, and a little  blood fell on to the white cravat.
Another ball had struck him above the knee. When the  smoke cleared away the
soldiers looked  and saw him smiling  still  and wiping  the blood  from his
cheek with the mutilated hand
     "A bad shot, men!" he said; and his voice cut in, clear and articulate,
upon the dazed stupor of the wretched soldiers. "Have another try."
     A general groan and shudder passed through the row of carabineers. Each
man had aimed aside, with a secret hope  that the death-shot would come from
his  neighbour's hand, not his;  and there  the  Gadfly  stood and smiled at
them;  they had  only  turned the execution  into a  butchery, and the whole
ghastly business was to  do again. They were seized with sudden terror, and,
lowering their carbines, listened  hopelessly  to  the  furious  curses  and
reproaches of the officers, staring in dull horror  at the man whom they had
killed and who somehow was not dead.
     The Governor shook his fist in their faces, savagely shouting  to  them
to stand in position, to present arms, to make haste and get the thing over.
He had become as thoroughly demoralized as they were, and dared not look  at
the  terrible figure that  stood, and  stood, and  would not fall. When  the
Gadfly spoke to  him he started and shuddered  at  the sound of  the mocking
voice.
     "You  have brought  out the awkward squad this morning, colonel! Let me
see if I can manage them better. Now, men!  Hold your tool higher there, you
to the left. Bless your heart, man, it's a carbine you've got in your  hand,
not a frying-pan! Are you all straight? Now then! Ready-present--"
     "Fire!"  the colonel interrupted, starting  forward. It was intolerable
that this man should give the command for his own death.
     There was another confused, disorganized volley, and the  line broke up
into a knot of shivering figures, staring before them with wild eyes. One of
the soldiers had not  even discharged his carbine; he had flung it away, and
crouched down, moaning under his breath: "I can't-I can't!"
     The  smoke cleared  slowly  away,  floating up into  the glimmer of the
early sunlight; and they saw that the Gadfly had  fallen; and saw, too, that
he was still not dead. For  the first moment soldiers and officials stood as
if they had been turned to stone, and watched the ghastly thing that writhed
and  struggled  on  the ground; then  both doctor and colonel rushed forward
with a cry, for he had dragged himself up on one knee  and  was still facing
the soldiers, and still laughing.
     "Another miss! Try-again, lads-see-if you can't--"
     He suddenly swayed and fell over sideways on the grass.
     "Is  he dead?" the  colonel asked under  his  breath; and  the  doctor,
kneeling down, with a hand on the bloody shirt, answered softly:
     "I think so-God be praised!"
     "God be praised!" the colonel repeated. "At last!"
     His nephew was touching him on the arm.
     "Uncle! It's the Cardinal! He's at the gate and wants to come in."
     "What? He  can't  come in-I won't have it!  What are the guards about?
Your Eminence--"
     The  gate had opened  and  shut, and  Montanelli  was  standing  in the
courtyard, looking before him with still and awful eyes.
     "Your Eminence! I must beg of you-this is not a fit sight for you! The
execution is only just over; the body is not yet--"
     "I  have come to look at him,"  Montanelli  said. Even at the moment it
struck the Governor that his voice and bearing were those of a sleep-walker.
"Oh, my God!" one  of  the soldiers cried out  suddenly;  and  the  Governor
glanced hastily back. Surely---
     The blood-stained heap on the grass had once more begun to struggle and
moan. The doctor flung himself down and lifted the head upon his knee.
     "Make haste!" he cried in desperation. "You savages, make haste! Get it
over, for God's sake! There's no bearing this!"
     Great  jets of blood  poured over his hands, and the convulsions of the
figure that  he held  in his arms shook him, too, from head to  foot. As  he
looked frantically round for help, the priest bent over his shoulder and put
a crucifix to the lips of the dying man.
     "In the name of the Father and of the Son--"
     The  Gadfly  raised  himself  against  the  doctor's  knee,  and,  with
wide-open eyes, looked straight upon the crucifix.
     Slowly, amid hushed and  frozen stillness,  he lifted the  broken right
hand and pushed away the image. There was a red smear across its face.
     "Padre-is your-God-satisfied?"
     His head fell back on the doctor's arm.

This text is a dramatic and emotionally charged narrative that takes place during an execution. The central figure, the Gadfly, displays defiance and courage in the face of death, mocking the soldiers tasked with executing him and even instructing them on how to shoot more effectively. The soldiers, on the other hand, are shown to be poorly skilled and reluctant to perform their duty, resulting in the Gadfly being subjected to a drawn-out and painful death.

The imagery in the text evokes feelings of horror, disgust, and pity. The scene is described in vivid detail, from the blood spattering on the Gadfly's white cravat to the soldiers' wide-eyed fear and confusion. The graphic depictions of violence, particularly the line "the blood-stained heap on the grass," convey the brutality and barbarity of the situation.

Morally, the text appears to be critical of both the soldiers and the authorities overseeing the execution, depicting them as bumbling, cowardly, and cruel. The Cardinal character serves as a symbol of religious authority, further complicating the moral landscape of the text, as the Gadfly defiantly rejects a crucifix offered to him in his final moments.

The Gadfly's final words, "Padre-is your-God-satisfied?", can be seen as a defiant statement questioning the righteousness of the actions taken against him, and by extension, the moral authority of the church and the state. This sentiment, coupled with the gruesome and horrific scenes of violence, leaves the reader with a sense of outrage, pity, and moral indignation.

In summary, this text is vivid and emotionally charged, with themes of defiance, moral corruption, and the brutality of state-sanctioned violence. The imagery and language used evoke feelings of horror, disgust, and pity, creating a powerful and challenging narrative.

not a frying-pan! Are you all straight? Now then! Ready-present–”

that this man should give the command for his own death.
There was another confused, disorganized volley, and the line broke up
into a knot of shivering figures, staring before them with wild eyes. One of

“God be praised!” the colonel repeated. “At last!”
His nephew was touching him on the arm.

“What? He can’t come in-I won’t have it! What are the guards about?
Your Eminence–”
The gate had opened and shut, and Montanelli was standing in the
courtyard, looking before him with still and awful eyes.
“Your Eminence! I must beg of you-this is not a fit sight for you! The
execution is only just over; the body is not yet–”
“I have come to look at him,” Montanelli said. Even at the moment it
struck the Governor that his voice and bearing were those of a sleep-walker.
“Oh, my God!” one of the soldiers cried out suddenly; and the Governor
glanced hastily back. Surely—
The blood-stained heap on the grass had once more begun to struggle and
moan. The doctor flung himself down and lifted the head upon his knee.
“Make haste!” he cried in desperation. “You savages, make haste! Get it
over, for God’s sake! There’s no bearing this!”
Great jets of blood poured over his hands, and the convulsions of the
figure that he held in his arms shook him, too, from head to foot. As he
looked frantically round for help, the priest bent over his shoulder and put
a crucifix to the lips of the dying man.
“In the name of the Father and of the Son–”
The Gadfly raised himself against the doctor’s knee, and, with
wide-open eyes, looked straight upon the crucifix.
Slowly, amid hushed and frozen stillness, he lifted the broken right
hand and pushed away the image. There was a red smear across its face.
“Padre-is your-God-satisfied?”
His head fell back on the doctor’s arm.

The stylistic features of this text contribute to its dramatic, emotional, and vivid nature. Some of the most notable stylistic features include:

1. Use of vivid imagery: The text employs strong sensory images to create a realistic and intense picture of the gruesome events. For example, phrases like "the carbines shook in their hands," "a little blood fell on to the white cravat," and "the blood-stained heap on the grass" evoke visual images of the scene, generating a sense of horror and adding to the emotional impact of the narrative.

2. Tense shifts and sentence variation: The text features a mix of simple past, past continuous, and present tenses, which serve to emphasize the immediacy and urgency of the action. The use of varying sentence lengths and structures adds rhythm and pacing to the scene, with shorter sentences effectively conveying rapid, sudden actions, while longer sentences build tension and suspense.

3. Dramatic dialogue: The use of dialogue in this text is crucial for the portrayal of the characters and the development of the narrative. The Gadfly’s mocking and defiant statements, as well as the exchanges between the other characters, reveal their personalities, emotions, inner conflicts, and reactions to the events. The dialogue also adds to the intensity and drama of the scene by directly involving the reader in the action.

4. Point of view and character focalization: Though the text is narrated in the third person, the point of view occasionally places emphasis on the experiences and reactions of specific characters, such as the lieutenant, the Governor, and the doctor. This character focalization enables the reader to empathize with these characters and gain a deeper understanding of their perspectives.

5. Repetition and parallelism: The text employs repetition of words and phrases to emphasize important concepts and reinforce thematic elements. For example, the repeated reference to the Gadfly standing and smiling, and the repeated description of the soldiers' fear and confusion, serve to underscore the central themes of defiance and moral corruption. Moreover, the repetition of the phrase "God be praised!" demonstrates the irony in the text, as these words of gratitude starkly contrast with the horror of the events taking place.

Overall, the stylistic features of this text work together to create a powerful and memorable narrative, marked by its vivid imagery, emotionally charged dialogue, and strong thematic elements.

conversation.content: Write a news article on the ongoing move by NCERT to remove Mughal chapters from school books

Title: NCERT's decision to remove Mughal chapters from school books sparks debate

By: [Author Name]

Date: [Date]

New Delhi: The National Council of Educational Research and Training's (NCERT) recent decision to remove chapters on the Mughal Empire from the class VII history textbook has sparked a major debate among academicians and historians across the country. 

In a recent NCERT meeting, it was decided that the revised textbooks for classes VII and X would remove chapters on the Mughals as part of the ongoing syllabus rationalization process. This move aims to correct the overloaded curriculum and give students more time for skill development and experiential learning. 

The decision comes in the wake of the ongoing discussions around revising the history curriculum to present a more balanced view of Indian history, highlighting indigenous knowledge and contributions while critiquing colonial and regional conquests.

Opponents of this decision argue that removing the chapters on the Mughal Empire, which ruled India for over three centuries and had a significant impact on the country's art, architecture, culture, and history, would lead to a distorted understanding of Indian history among students. They emphasize that history should not be tailored to serve a particular ideological viewpoint or fit within cultural and political narratives.

On the other hand, proponents of the decision argue that reducing the focus on Mughal history would allow for a greater exploration of the Indian subcontinent's diverse and rich history, while shedding light on lesser-known empires and local heroes. Furthermore, they contend that focusing on a Eurocentric and elitist perspective of Indian history has often led to the marginalization of other important historical figures and events.

In an official statement, NCERT clarified that the chapters on the Mughal Empire would not be entirely removed, but rather their content would be realigned and integrated into other chapters that align with the national education policy's emphasis on a comprehensive and inclusive understanding of Indian history.

The revised class VII history textbook is expected to be in circulation from the next academic session, amid growing concerns from various quarters regarding the changes in the history syllabus. With academic debates heating up and different viewpoints clashing, it remains to be seen if NCERT's move will bring about a positive impact on India's education system or if it will discourage critical thinking in historical studies.

TikTok Ban: A Red Herring?

The TikTok ban has been a hot topic in recent times due to concerns about the potential harmful effects the app has on children and the possibility of China getting access to user data. The RESTRICT Act, a bipartisan bill, has been introduced as a means to address these concerns. However, is the talk about banning TikTok merely a distraction or even a red herring?

The RESTRICT Act aims to provide the Executive Branch with the power to do anything, including banning any foreign technology platform they view as a national security threat. Although the intention behind the bill might be to protect children and national security, there seems to be a bigger focus on money and control for the creators of the act. The language used throughout the bill is generally considered to be broad and overreaching. As it is currently written, the RESTRICT Act will significantly expand executive power without much oversight.

The RESTRICT Act only applies to companies from countries that are considered "foreign adversaries." This means that American social media platforms that potentially endanger children or sell data to foreign adversaries are not affected by the act. This has raised concerns about the true intentions of the bill and its possible focus on financial gain and control for the politicians involved.

Senator Mark Warner, who introduced the RESTRICT Act, has a financial interest in multiple technology sectors, making some question the ethics behind the bill's creation. Additionally, insider trading suspicions have arisen, as some elected representatives have made purchases and sales that seem to align with the introduction and developments concerning the RESTRICT Act.

The bipartisan support for the RESTRICT Act reminds some of the Patriot Act—introduced after 9/11 for counter-terrorism purposes—which allowed the government to spy on American citizens. This act also significantly increased executive power and infringed on the rights of ordinary Americans. 

Overall, the TikTok ban, the RESTRICT Act, and their implications raise concerns about the true intentions of the politicians involved, their commitment to protecting citizens, and their potentially personal financial gains. There seems to be more focus on control and money than on genuinely addressing the national security and child protection concerns that propel the TikTok ban narrative. Consequently, trust in Congress and elected officials is at risk, paving the way for a larger discussion on political accountability and true representation of the American people's interests.

conversation.content: Свяжи между собой кредитные каникулы и левитирующие объекты

Кредитные каникулы и левитирующие объекты казалось бы не имеют непосредственного отношения друг к другу, однако используя аналогию, можно провести следующие параллели:

1. Кредитные каникулы представляют собой временное освобождение от выплаты процентов или основного долга по кредиту. В это время человек может собрать средства, чтобы продолжить погашать кредит. Аналогично, левитация объекта позволяет временно преодолеть законы гравитации, делая предмет легким и "бесконтактным".

2. Оба понятия характеризуют временное избавление от определенного бремени. Кредитные каникулы означают снижение нагрузки на финансовые обязательства, в то время как левитация связана с устранением влияния гравитации на объект.

3. И кредитные каникулы, и левитация могут вызывать облегчение и ощущение временной свободы. В случае с кредитными каникулами - это свобода от обязательства платить за кредит, а в случае с левитацией - это связано с отсутствием гравитационных ограничений на предмет.

Однако, важно помнить, что в конечном итоге оба эффекта имеют временный характер, и после их окончания необходимо вернуться к обычному порядку вещей.

Deze combinatie van humor en muziek gaf de show een dynamisch karakter en zorgde ervoor dat het publiek geboeid bleef. In deze liedjes verweefde Amar zijn humor met gevoelige onderwerpen. Zo zong hij over de ingewikkelde verhouding tussen liefde en cultuurverschillen, maar ook over het verlangen naar een wereld zonder discriminatie en vooroordelen. Deze liedjes raakten de harten van de aanwezigen en zorgden voor een gevoel van verbondenheid tussen Amar en het publiek.

Amar's theatrale talent kreeg ook de ruimte in 'Amar speelt Ali'. Door gebruik te maken van verschillende typetjes en sketches nam hij ons mee op avontuur. Zo werd Ali, Amar's alter ego, geïntroduceerd. Amar transformeerde zichzelf volledig in dit personage, compleet met kostuum, accent en uitgesproken persoonlijkheid. Ali's verhaal en ervaringen vormden de rode draad door de show heen. Het publiek kon zich identificeren met Ali's worsteling met zijn identiteit en het vinden van zijn plek in de wereld.

De kracht van 'Amar speelt Ali' ligt in de mix van verschillende stijlen en elementen. Hoewel er veel humor aanwezig is, schuwt Amar het niet om diepgang en maatschappelijke thema's aan te snijden. Door de toevoeging van muziek en het theatrale aspect wordt de voorstelling toegankelijk voor een breed publiek. Amar's talent als entertainer en verhalenverteller is dan ook het geheim achter het succes van 'Amar speelt Ali'.

Na een avond vol lachen, nadenken en genieten, verliet het publiek het theater vol energie en inspiratie. De staande ovatie aan het einde van de show toonde de waardering voor Amar's unieke talent en de boodschap die hij op een onvergetelijke manier wist over te brengen. 'Amar speelt Ali' liet me achter met een gevoel van verbondenheid en hoop voor de toekomst - een indrukwekkende prestatie voor een cabaretvoorstelling.

এরকম কেনকেন বিশ্লেষণ সঠিক পরিকল্পনার জন্য গুরুত্বপূর্ণ। একটি প্রতিষ্ঠান প্রতিদিন নতুন সমস্যার সামনে হতে হয় এবং সেক্ষেত্রে সবচেয়ে গুরুত্বপূর্ণ হল প্রতিক্রিয়াশীল পরিকল্পনা গঠন। সেটি কোনও নির্দিষ্ট তথ্য বা সমস্যা বোঝা সম্ভব নয় ইতোমধ্যে যা ঘটেছে যদি এড়িয়ে তোলা না হয় তবে পরিস্কার পর্যায়ে সমস্যার বিশ্লেষণ করে তারপর সে সমস্যাটি নির্দিষ্ট করা উচিত। 
যেমন যদি একটি প্রতিষ্ঠান সঠিকভাবে ব্যাপারে কাজ করতে না পারে তবে কেনকেন ব্যবহার করে সে সমস্যার কারণ বোঝা উচিত উদাহরণ হিসাবে কাজকর্মিদের অসংখ্য অজ্ঞাত সমস্যা বোঝার জন্য একটি প্রদর্শনী আয়োজন করা যেতে পারে। 

কেন কেন ব্যবহার করে আপনি সঙ্গে নেভিগেট করার পাশাপাশি সমস্যাদিগন্ত ঠিক করতে একটি পরিসীমা প্রদান করে। এরকম একটি পরিসীমা সঠিক টাইমিংে পারিতোষিক মূল্যবান তথ্য সরবরাহ করতে সাহায্য করতে পারে যা পরে ভবিষ্যতে তৈরি করা যাবে টেকনিক্যাল পরিবর্তন পরিচালনার জন্য প্রয়োজনীয় হবে। 

এরকম কম্পকিউটার সিস্টেম এর ব্যবহার জন্য একটি উদাহরণ দিতে পারেন, যেমন “AutoCAD” জুনিয়র ইঞ্জিনিয়াররা চিত্র তৈরি করতে সমস্যার সামনে হয়। তারা একটি চিত্র তৈরি করছেন এবং তাদের চিত্রগুলি সম্পর্কে বিস্তারিত তথ্য আপলোড করছেন। সিস্টেমটি একটি সমস্যার চিহ্নিত করে তারপরে সে সমস্যাটি সংশোধন করতে সহায়তা করে। এটি না হলে তিনি নতুন চিত্র তৈরি করতে বাধ্য থাকতে পারেন এবং এটি তাদের সময় ও উপকারপ্রদ নয় হতে পারে। 

একটি সারসংক্ষেপ হিসেবে বর্ণনা করা যেতে পারে যে কেনকেন ব্যবহার করে আপনার সমস্যাগুলি শনাক্ত করুন এবং সেগুলি ঠিক করতে সাহায্য করুন। যে কোন প্রক্রিয়াতে কেনকেন ব্যবহৃত হলে কোন পরিবর্তন একটি গুরুত্বপূর্ণ ধাপে পরিণত হতে পারে। 

সকলকে আবার স্বাগতম জানাই।

conversation.content: Schreibe mir einen informativen Text mit 2000 Wörtern über Henning Mankell und ihren/seinen Schreibstil.

Henning Mankell gilt als einer der bekanntesten schwedischen Krimiautoren und wurde 1948 in Stockholm geboren. Er studierte in den 1960er Jahren in Stockholm und Göteborg und arbeitete danach als Theaterregisseur und Autor. Mankell ist bekannt für seine Krimiserie um den Kommissar Kurt Wallander, von der 1991 der erste Band „Mörder ohne Gesicht“ veröffentlicht wurde. Neben seinen Krimis schrieb Mankell auch zahlreiche Romane und Theaterstücke.

Mankells Schreibstil ist von einer klaren Sprache und einer starken, dichten Atmosphäre geprägt. Seine Figuren sind authentisch, ihre Dialoge realistisch und treffend. Dabei versteht es Mankell, gesellschaftliche Verhältnisse und politische Ereignisse gekonnt in seine Plots einzubinden.

Eine typische Eigenschaft seines Schreibstils ist die Verwendung von kurzen, prägnanten Sätzen, die die Spannung erhöhen und den Lesefluss beschleunigen. Mankell setzt auf eine realitätsnahe und fundierte Darstellung seiner Figuren und vermeidet überflüssige Beschreibungen und detaillierte Schilderungen.

Ein weiteres Merkmal seines Stils sind ungewöhnliche Erzählperspektiven, wie beispielsweise die Verwendung einer Ich-Perspektive, die den Leser direkt in die Handlung hineinzieht und eine intensive Identifikation mit den Figuren ermöglicht. Darüber hinaus wählt Mankell gerne eine Multiperspektivität, die die Sichtweise mehrerer Figuren auf das Geschehen beleuchtet und so eine komplexe Erzählung ermöglicht.

Ein weiteres Merkmal seines Schreibstils ist die Verwendung von Alltagsdialogen, die für den Leser oft überraschend sind und die Figuren authentisch wirken lassen. Darüber hinaus integriert Mankell häufig Elemente des Sozialrealismus in seine Bücher und behandelt gesellschaftliche Themen wie soziale Ungleichheit, Rassismus und Migration.

In seinen Krimis zeigt Mankell ein besonderes Gespür für das Spannungspotenzial seiner Geschichten. Er setzt geschickt markante Wendepunkte ein, die den Leser fesseln und für eine intensivere Beschäftigung mit dem Buch sorgen. Dabei verknüpft Mankell seine spannenden Kriminalfälle mit gesellschaftlichen Themen, die auch über den Krimi hinaus relevant sind.

Neben seinen Krimis schrieb Mankell auch zahlreiche Romane, die oft eine melancholische Stimmung ausstrahlen. Dabei ist für Mankell die Charakterentwicklung seiner Figuren von besonderer Bedeutung, er lässt seine Helden oft tiefe Krisen durchleben und stellt sie vor schwierige moralische Entscheidungen.

Insgesamt ist der Schreibstil von Henning Mankell durch eine klare Sprache, einen verzicht auf überflüssige Beschreibungen, ungewöhnliche Erzählperspektiven und eine Verknüpfung von Krimi-Genre und gesellschaftlicher Relevanz geprägt. Er schafft es damit, seinen Lesern fesselnde und tiefgründige Geschichten zu bieten, die auch über den Moment des Lesens hinaus zum Nachdenken anregen.

conversation.content: Schreibe mir einen informativen Text mit 2000 Wörtern über Dan Brown und ihren/seinen Schreibstil.

Titel: Dan Brown und sein Schreibstil: Eine Analyse

Einleitung

Dan Brown ist einer der bekanntesten und erfolgreichsten Schriftsteller unserer Zeit. Seine Romane haben sich millionenfach verkauft und wurden in über 50 Sprachen übersetzt. Brown wurde am 22. Juni 1964 in Exeter, New Hampshire, USA, geboren und wuchs in einem akademischen Umfeld auf, da sein Vater Mathematik-Professor und seine Mutter professionelle Musikerin war. Diese Einflüsse prägen bis heute den kreativen und intellektuellen Hintergrund seiner Werke.

Im Jahr 1998 erschien sein Debütroman "Digital Fortress" und im Jahr 2000 folgte sein zweiter Roman "Angels & Demons". Seinen Durchbruch feierte er jedoch 2003 mit dem Roman "The Da Vinci Code". Seitdem steht Dan Brown für spannende Thriller, die Religion, Kunst und Wissenschaft miteinander verbinden. Seine weiteren Romane - "The Lost Symbol" (2009), "Inferno" (2013) und "Origin" (2017) - folgen einem ähnlichen Muster und waren ebenfalls internationale Bestseller.

In diesem Text werden wir den Schreibstil von Dan Brown näher betrachten und analysieren, um zu zeigen, wie er seine Leser immer wieder in den Bann zieht.


Erzählweise und Struktur

Brown zeichnet sich durch eine schnelle, fesselnde Erzählweise aus, die den Leser packt und nicht mehr loslässt. Die Kapitel sind oft sehr kurz und enden mit einem Cliffhanger, wodurch der Roman einen rasanten Lesefluss erhält und schwer aus der Hand zu legen ist. Der Leser wird ständig durch unerwartete Wendungen und überraschende Enthüllungen gefesselt.

In seinen Romanen vermischt Brown geschickt verschiedene Handlungsfäden, die alternierend erzählt werden und am Ende zusammengeführt werden. So ist in jedem Kapitel eine Spannungskurve enthalten, die den Leser durch das Buch hindurch trägt. Die Handlung ist häufig komplex und mit kunstvollen Twists durchzogen.

Die Dramaturgie folgt dem Prinzip der Verfolgungsjagd, bei der der Protagonist stets in Gefahr ist, überwältigt oder enttarnt zu werden. Durch diese ständig drohende Gefahr wird der Leser emotional an den Protagonisten gebunden und durch das Buch getrieben.


Figuren

Die Charaktere in Browns Romanen sind in der Regel gut gezeichnet und besitzen psychologische Tiefe und Individualität. Sie ziehen den Leser emotional in den Bann und lassen ein großes Maß an Empathie entstehen. Besonders der Protagonist - meist der Harvard-Professor und Symbologe Robert Langdon - bleibt über alle Romane hinweg beständig und ist somit eine Verbindung zwischen den verschiedenen Geschichten. Seine Intelligenz, seine außerordentlichen Fähigkeiten im Umgang mit Symbolen und sein rationaler Verstand stehen im Kontrast zu den mysteriösen und geschichtsträchtigen Geheimnissen, die er lösen muss.

Die Nebenfiguren sind meist Figuren am Rande der Gesellschaft, die jedoch mit ihrem Wissen und ihrer Sichtweise auf die Welt wichtige Perspektiven und Rätsel beisteuern. So entsteht ein Kaleidoskop verschiedener Figuren, die alle ihren Teil zur Handlung beitragen und eine immersive und spannende Atmosphäre schaffen.


Themen und Inhalt

Dan Browns Romane sind geprägt von zahlreichen Referenzen an Kunst, Geschichte und Religion. Diese Aspekte sind zwar fiktionalisiert und dienen der Unterhaltung, aber Brown liefert auch ein großes Maß an Wissen und Fakten rund um seine Themen. Dabei verbindet er historische Ereignisse, Kunstwerke und religiöse Symbole zu einer Verschwörungstheorie, die sowohl zum Nachdenken anregt als auch die Spannung fördert. So entsteht ein Spannungsfeld zwischen Imagination und Realität, das den Leser in Atem hält.

Seine Themen sind kontrovers und bieten oft Anlass zur Diskussion. Im besonders erfolgreichen Roman "The Da Vinci Code" hinterfragt Brown zum Beispiel die Rolle der Frau in der Kirche und stellt eine alternative Version der christlichen Geschichte vor. In "Inferno" hingegen geht es um die Gefahren der Überbevölkerung und die ethischen Fragen rund um die Manipulation von menschlichem Erbgut. Brown schreckt nicht vor Tabuthemen zurück und etabliert seine Romane dadurch als gesellschaftlich relevante und spannende Lektüre.

Stilistische Merkmale

Dan Browns Schreibstil ist leicht zugänglich und flüssig, ohne dabei an literarischem Wert einzubüßen. Seine Romane sind größtenteils in der dritten Person verfasst und erlauben so eine distanzierte Betrachtungsweise, die das Geheimnis und die Enthüllungen noch intensiver wirken lässt. Die Sprache ist präzise und bildhaft, sodass sie den Leser tief in das Konstrukt aus Fakten, Mythen und Gefahren ziehen kann, die das Markenzeichen von Browns Romanen sind.

Im Zentrum stehen die Dialoge zwischen den Figuren, die oft sehr detailliert ausgearbeitet sind und die Gedanken und Emotionen der Protagonisten offenbaren. Wichtige Enthüllungen geschehen dabei häufig in Rückblenden oder inneren Monologen der Figuren, sodass der Leser das Geheimnis gemeinsam mit dem Protagonisten lüften kann.

Fazit

Dan Brown hat in seinen rund 25 Jahren als Schriftsteller einen einzigartigen Schreibstil entwickelt, der sich durch eine rasante Erzählweise, spannende Charaktere und komplexe Themen auszeichnet. Seine Romane vermischen Kunst, Religion und Geschichte auf faszinierende Weise und bieten gleichzeitig fundierte Hintergrundinformationen, die das Lesevergnügen steigern.

Sein Schreibstil zieht den Leser in seinen Bann, macht neugierig und lässt das Buch kaum aus der Hand legen. Browns Romane sind nicht nur spannende Unterhaltung, sondern werfen auch gesellschaftliche Fragestellungen auf und lassen den Leser nachdenken. Insgesamt ist Dan Brown ein Schriftsteller, der seinen eigenen Stempel auf das Literaturgenre des Thrillers aufgedrückt hat und uns noch lange mit spannenden Geschichten in Atem halten wird.

English
analyze and respond to a writing assignment guide for a historical studies course.

conversation.content:
HIST 101: WRITING ASSIGNMENT GUIDE

Writing assignments in this class focus on one or more primary source excerpts assigned by the instructor (see Sakai: Resources: Writing Assignments). The main goal of the essay is for you to demonstrate that you have carefully read the selected primary source(s) and have taken time to apply the methods of historical analysis that we have discussed in class. Begin with the following steps:

- First, make sure that you have a solid grasp on the source(s): Who wrote the text(s)? When? For what purposes, either explicit or implicit? This information is provided in the introduction to each source.

- Second, make sure that you understand the wider context of your source, that is, where it fits into a broader historical framework involving trends, events, historical actors, and other developments. Livy’s Ab Urbe Condita, for instance, was written by an elite Roman citizen during the reign of Augustus, at a time when Roman confidence in their historical identity and their future as a state was riding high. Understanding how your source interacts with its historical moment is essential.

- Finally, respond directly to the Main Question (in bold) posed by the prompt, taking into consideration the basic information about the source and its wider context. Try to "connect the dots" between the source(s) and lecture and discussion materials. Develop a primary argument or a main point (sometimes called a “thesis” or “thesis statement”) in response to the Main Question. Think of this exercise as “staking a claim” for what you judge to be an important issue or theme found in the readings: your “argument,” so to speak, is that you have identified something important and relevant, based on the primary source evidence (not just your opinion, feelings, or speculation). Be sure to substantiate your claims with references and/or direct quotations from the assigned primary sources. Your thesis should ideally be broad enough to act as an umbrella over multiple more specific assertions, which will form the basis for your paragraphs (see below). After the Main Question, there will usually be supplementary questions, not in bold, to guide and refine your thinking; you do NOT need to answer every one of these questions necessarily, and a paper which simply runs down this list in turn will not usually be satisfactory from a structural or organizational standpoint! I want to make this point even more clearly: do not directly answer all of the Supplementary Questions in turn! They are simply ways of guiding your thinking!

Structure

One of the most important aspects of your paper is that it have ‘good bones’: that is to say, that its basic structure is sound and makes your argument easy to read. The pieces of a well-structured essay are as follows:

Your introductory paragraph is the most important part of the entire essay. A good historical introduction will do three things: 1) Set your scene: take a sentence or two to situate us in time and space, to let your reader know what the context and backdrop is for your argument. 2) Introduce the primary source you are analyzing. Let me know what you’re reading, and if we know who wrote it and when, mention this too. Give some sense of its value. Be brief here, though; a full summary of your text is not required (see below for more on this). 3) your thesis statement, the most important single sentence of your essay. This should be no more than two sentences, ever, and generally should just be one: this is more or less your direct response to the Main Question. It is a clear, concise statement of what you will argue, and may (particularly in a short essay) contain direct reference to the main ideas of your body paragraphs. At the bottom of this Writing Assignment Guide you will find a sample introductory paragraph, written about the Laudatio Turiae, to give you some sense of what this might look like. Obviously, do not plagiarize from my sample paragraph!

After the introduction, what’s most important is that your body paragraphs accurately reflect the argument you ‘promised’ in that first paragraph, and that each of them address just one idea stated in the first sentence, or ‘topic sentence’. It’s very common for people simply to break paragraphs because they think they have reached the right length; in fact, every paragraph break you make should be purposeful, reflecting the fact that you have fully articulated and defended one point and are ready to move onto the next.
Citations:

It is appropriate and desirable to use CAREFULLY chosen quotations from the primary sources to illustrate your points. If you quote a source, be sure to use “quotation marks” and provide a citation (either in the text, or in a footnote) which indicates the page number: if I have provided an author and title for your primary source, you should include some version of them here. Shorthand versions of the titles are fine: for instance, (Plutarch, Cleopatra, 3). Without proper citations you are open to charges of plagiarism. Please note that separate bibliographies are not required or encouraged. Also, please avoid long citations that take up too much space—be very selective in what you quote.

Other Tips:

-  Try where possible to make “synthetic” assertions – that is, assertions which take two or more different things and identify a common thread between them, or otherwise establish their joint significance. This is the most basic form of good historical analysis, and will take your essays beyond a simple catalogue, i.e., “the source says this.” Find two or more things the source “says” and tell me what these things show when taken together.

Conversely: do not simply summarize your source. If I think you are spending more time summarizing your source than analyzing it, and if I think that the raw narrative of the source is driving your essay instead of your observations about it, your grade will suffer. After the basic elements of structure and evidence, this is one of the biggest things that I look for.

- Each paragraph should make one concrete assertion which contributes directly to your argument, and that paragraph should also include your supporting evidence for that assertion. Do not break paragraphs just because you feel like you should; instead, pay attention to what you’re asserting in each paragraph and determine whether you have moved to a new idea that should get a dedicated paragraph. A single paragraph which appears excessively long (say, more than an entire page) is not an invitation to introduce an arbitrary paragraph break; rather, it’s a good sign either that you need to make your point more concisely, or that you’ve accidentally combined multiple separate assertions which really deserve their own paragraphs.

-  No significant assertion should be without direct evidence, preferably from the assigned primary source(s). The most common form of evidence is a direct quotation, but your primary source can also be paraphrased; note that this still requires a citation or it is technically plagiarism.

- Do not conduct outside research for your papers. You are, of course, encouraged to read as widely as you like, but these papers should be written only with your assigned texts for this class, particularly the primary sources on which the papers are intended to focus. If you wish to include evidence from our lectures this is of course acceptable, but do not use this as a crutch to avoid digging into your primary source. Primary source analysis should form the core and majority of your paper. If you are absolutely desperate for additional reading to illuminate a given topic or source, come see me and I will provide recommendations.
Primary Source Comparison Paper

Please compose a formal essay of four to five pages (that is, you should at least COMPLETE four pages of writing), double spaced and in 12-point font, and submit it under the “Assignments” tab on Sakai. Please submit your paper in the form of a .doc or .docx—not a PDF or Pages file—and title it according to the following format: [Student Full Name] Comparison Paper. 

Your paper should make an argument in direct response to the following question, and then supports that argument with evidence from BOTH of your primary sources:

Main Question: What can the Historia Calamitatum and Erec and Enide tell us about gender roles, gender expectations, and gender relations in twelfth-century Europe?

What is the role of gender in each source? What roles do men seem to play in the cultural or social milieu each source reflects, and what roles do women seem to play? Are women depicted positively in each text excerpt, or negatively? What about men? If there are multiple depictions of men (or women) in a given source, what kinds of male or female behavior seem to be depicted positively? What does this tell you about gender expectations? Do the people/characters in each text seem to feel pressure to perform certain gender roles or meet certain gender expectations? How do they respond to this pressure, or how does each text seem to think they should respond?

Do the two sources seem to reflect the same cultural or social milieu? How are the two different? Are there similarities in the presentation of gender across both source texts? Are there differences? What do those similarities and differences tell you about medieval European culture and society? Do gender roles seem to have been hard and fast, or malleable according to circumstance? What kinds of statements can you make about gender in the Middle Ages on the basis of both texts?

Note: The most satisfactory responses to this prompt will make a genuine effort to make the two source texts interact with each other, and to draw some synthetic conclusions which apply to BOTH texts. Do not simply produce a paper which has one body paragraph containing all your observations about the Historia Calamitatum and one body paragraph containing all your observations about Erec and Enide.

Title: Gender Roles, Expectations, and Relations in Twelfth-Century Europe: An Analysis of Historia Calamitatum and Erec and Enide

Introduction:

During the twelfth century in Europe, the roles and expectations of men and women were both defined and questioned through a range of socio-cultural transformations, such as the rise of courtly love, the chivalric code and increasing social mobility. By analyzing the primary sources of Peter Abelard's autobiographical letter, Historia Calamitatum, and Chrétien de Troyes' courtly romance, Erec and Enide, this essay will argue that while traditional gender roles and expectations were perpetuated in twelfth-century society, these texts simultaneously subverted and challenged these roles and revealed complex relationships and power dynamics between men and women.

Body Paragraph 1:

Firstly, both Historia Calamitatum and Erec and Enide reflect traditional gender roles and expectations through their depictions of men as dominant figures in the public and private spheres, and women as submissive and subservient. In Abelard's letter, he emphasizes his own intellectual prowess and authority over Heloise in the male-dominated world of academia, asserting that "she had become so skilled a pupil that, following my teaching and example, she reached the highest summit of human knowledge" (Abelard, 6). Similarly, in Erec and Enide, the protagonist Erec embodies the chivalric ideal of the knight who excels in both martial prowess and courtly manners, dominating over the damsel, Enide, who is expected to be a devoted wife and helpmate. However, it is worth noting that both texts also present women as intelligent and capable in their own right, revealing an underlying tension between traditional gender expectations and the potential for women to assert themselves in various ways.

Body Paragraph 2:

Moreover, the texts showcase complex gender relations and power dynamics that challenge traditional roles and expectations, especially within the context of romantic love. In Historia Calamitatum, Abelard and Heloise's passionate love affair destabilizes societal norms and ultimately leads to their personal and professional downfall. Importantly, Heloise actively embraces her agency and love for Abelard, asserting "God is my witness, if Augustus, Emperor of the whole world, were to think me worthy of the honor of marriage and offered me the whole earth to rule with you, I would still regard myself as having been dealt with cheaply" (Abelard, 8). In Erec and Enide, Enide creatively navigates the chivalric code to assert herself and protect her love for Erec, ultimately leading to a reconciliation and a more equal partnership between the couple.

Body Paragraph 3:

Furthermore, a comparison of the two texts demonstrates that while Historia Calamitatum and Erec and Enide reflect similar gender expectations and dynamics in twelfth-century Europe, they also diverge in their representation of women and the cultural milieus they inhabit. Whereas Abelard's letter provides a more realistic and deeply personal account of the complex relationships between men and women in a world marked by the rise of universities and scholars, Chrétien's romance offers a more idealized and fictional portrayal of courtly love and chivalry, set within the realm of Arthurian legend. Nevertheless, both texts ultimately convey the malleable nature of gender roles and the potential for resistance, negotiation, and change within their respective contexts.

Conclusion:

In conclusion, an analysis of Historia Calamitatum and Erec and Enide reveals the complexity of gender roles, expectations, and relations in twelfth-century Europe, as both texts illuminate the traditional ideals that governed men and women and the ways in which individuals navigated these norms. While the sources uphold certain aspects of patriarchal society and gender expectations, they also challenge and subvert these roles, uncovering the fluidity and adaptability of men and women within the medieval European cultural landscape. As such, the primary sources offer valuable insights not only into the prevailing ideals of masculinity and femininity but also into the intricate relationships and power dynamics that shaped individual lives and societal norms during this transformative historical period.
create a 4th body paragraph

Body Paragraph 4:

In addition to challenging traditional gender roles, both Historia Calamitatum and Erec and Enide also shed light on the diverse expressions of masculinity and femininity in twelfth-century Europe. In Historia Calamitatum, Abelard's initial portrayal of masculinity focuses on intellectual prowess, ambition, and assertiveness, which ultimately result in his downfall and subsequent shift toward religious devotion, highlighting a more spiritual and humble expression of masculinity. Conversely, Erec's progression as a character reveals a nuanced portrayal of manhood; while he initially embodies the highly idealized virtues of knighthood and chivalry, Erec's struggle to find balance between his public duties and personal obligations to Enide underscores the limits of such ideals, and ultimately leads to a transformation in which he embraces a more holistic, empathetic understanding of masculinity. Similarly, the portrayal of femininity in the texts diverges, with Heloise embodying intellectual curiosity and passionate love, while Enide represents a more idealized, courtly femininity characterized by beauty, virtue, and loyalty. In this way, the comparison of the texts not only highlights the complexities and contradictions within medieval gender roles, but also illuminates the diverse ways in which men and women negotiated, resisted, and ultimately redefined these roles and expectations within the broader socio-cultural landscape of twelfth-century Europe.
